thread.title: $A lower as new Greek bailout deal struck
thread.title_full: $A lower as new Greek bailout deal struck

title: $A lower as new Greek bailout deal struck
text:
Tue, Jul 14, 2015, 10:20 PM AEST - Australia Markets closed $A lower as new Greek bailout deal struck AAP – 4 hours ago Print 
The Australian dollar is weaker as the greenback strengthens on the back of Greece's new debt deal. 
At 1700 AEST on Tuesday, the currency was trading at 74.28 US cents, down from 74.54 cents on Monday. 
An agreement between Greece and its international creditors on a new bailout program eased concerns about the state of the euro zone. 
Traders bought back into the US dollar ahead of US Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen's testimony to congress this week, which will be analysed for clues about a looming rate hike. 
The Australian dollar got a small lift from the release of strong local business confidence numbers, National Australia Bank global co-head of FX strategy Ray Attrill said. 
NAB's confidence barometer rose two points in June to 10 points - its highest level in nearly two years. 
The currency jumped nearly a quarter of a per cent to 74.25 US cents soon after the release of the business survey, where it hovered for the remainder of the local trading session, he said. 
At 1700 AEST, the Australian dollar was at 91.69 Japanese yen, up from 91.68 yen on Monday, and at 67.65 euro cents, up from 66.66 euro cents. 
The next event set to influence the Australian dollar is Tuesday night's US retail sales report for June, Mr Attrill said. 
"If (those) numbers are strong, then chances are that will play to a continuation of a stronger US dollar," he said. 
"Which would probably mean that the Aussie dollar will struggle. 
"And then we've got Janet Yellen speaking again in the evening, so it'll be an interesting 48 hours." 
The bond market was weaker after US bonds sold off as fears about Greece's debt crisis eased. 
CMC Markets chief analyst Ric Spooner said the stronger than expected local business confidence figures also had a negative impact. 
"It certainly does tilt the balance against any further prospects of rate cuts by the RBA," he said. 
At 1630 AEST on Tuesday, the September 2015 10-year bond futures contract was trading at 96.930 (implying a yield of 3.070 per cent), down from 96.955 (3.045 per cent) on Monday. 
The September 2015 three-year bond futures contract was at 97.950 (2.050 per cent), down from 97.980 (2.020 per cent). @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook NSW mine is 'a threat to all farming' AAP
